evidence.text: Herein, we show that neutrophils also have the ability to express and release MIP-3alpha/CCL20 and MIP-3beta/CCL19 when cultured with either LPS or TNF-alpha.
In this report, we found that IL-17A, IL-22, and tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-alpha stimulated CCL20 expression by KC.

In these studies, we described the ability of primary cultured human AECs and BEAS-2B cells to synthesize and secrete MIP3a/CCL20. We demonstrated the release of this chemokine in response to low concentrations of a diverse group of cytokines, including the pro-inflammatory agents TNF-α and IL-1β and the Th2 cytokines IL-4 and IL-13.
The ability of IL-1 to enhance CCL5 and CCL20 expression induced by TNF-alpha and IFN-gamma was inhibited in a similar manner (data not shown).
IRAK1 is required for IL-1 enhancement of TNF-alpha or IFN-gamma induced CCL5 and CCL20 expression.
Stimulation of IEC with CCL20 and proinflammatory stimuli (TNF-alpha, IL-1beta, LPS) significantly upregulates CCL20 mRNA expression.
CCL20 production was synergistically augmented by a combination of IL-1beta, TNF-alpha, and IL-17.

In TNF-α-stimulated cells with silenced Ref-1 expression, the levels of IL-8, MIP-3α, or Gro-α mRNA expression were significantly inhibited by 62%, 49%, or 33%, respectively (P< 0.05) compared to scrambled siRNA-transfected cells ( ).
The current study demonstrates that silencing of Ref-1 expression significantly inhibited TNF-α-induced IL-8 mRNA and protein expression, as well as TNF-α-stimulated MIP-3α and Gro-α mRNA expression.
The expression of CCL20 in keratinocytes is induced by TNF-alpha, IL-1beta, CD40 ligand, IFN-gamma and IL-17 [XREF_BIBR], and therefore IL-1beta might be an inducer of CCL20 in TGM1 deficiency.
IL-17A, IL-22, and TNF-α stimulated CCL20 mRNA and protein production in a dose- and time-dependent manner ( ).

Both TNF-α and IL-17A injections led to concomitant increases in CCL20 protein levels in cytokine-injected ears ( ), whereas interleukin-22-injected ears showed no clear elevations in CCL20 protein expression in these experiments.
The production of MIP-3alpha was markedly increased over the basal level after treatment with IL-1alpha and TNF-alpha in a dose-dependent manner.
In mice, intradermal injection of IL-1alpha and TNF-alpha rapidly induced a local accumulation of transcripts for LARC/CCL20 and its receptor CCR6 with a lag of several hours in the latter.
It is thus possible that enhanced Tnf-alpha and Il-1beta production in Tg-KLK5 contributes to Ccl20 expression leading to Th17 recruitment.

TNF was demonstrated to induce the expression of KDR (kinase insert domain receptor) [XREF_BIBR], CCL20 (chemokine ligand 200 [XREF_BIBR], CXCL10 (chemokine ligand 10) [XREF_BIBR] and BF (B-factor, properdin) [XREF_BIBR].
We showed that adipocyte culture medium increased the production of TNF-alpha in MDA-MB-231 cells, which stimulated CCL20 expression in an autocrine fashion.
Trim32 significantly increased, whereas Piasy repressed, TNFalpha and IL-17A induction of CCL20 expression (XREF_FIG).

Moreover, we show that the proinflammatory cytokines interleukin-1beta and tumor necrosis factor-alpha, but not interferon-gamma, induce expression of CCL20 mRNA and secretion of CCL20 protein in cultures of mouse brain-derived astrocytes.

evidence.text: Additive increases in keratinocyte-derived IL-17C, TNFα, IL-8, IL-1α/β, IL-1F5, IL-6, S100A8/A9 and lipocalin 2 (LCN2) were observed along with synergistic increases in keratinocyte-derived IL-1F9, IL-19, CCL20, S100A7, hBD2 (DEFB4) and peptidase inhibitor 3 following stimulation with IL-17C/TNFα.

p38 phosphorylates Tip60 at Thr158/106 in vitro and in cells.
Thus, Tip60 is phosphorylated by activated p38 in cells.
Tip60 was phosphorylated by all 4 recombinant p38 isoforms in a MKK6E dependent manner (XREF_FIG).
Oncogenic ras induces p38 mediated phosphorylation of Tip60 at Thr158/106 in senescent cells.

These findings indicate that upon activation by oncogenic ras in senescent cells, p38alpha and p38delta, but not p38gamma, mediate the phosphorylation of Tip60 at Thr158/106, despite the fact that all 4 p38 isoforms could phosphorylate Tip60 in vitro (XREF_FIG).

Moreover, the T182A mutation of the p38 phosphorylation site on PRAK, which rendered PRAK unphosphorylatable by p38, significantly reduced acetylation of PRAK by Tip60 despite intact Tip60 phosphorylation by p38 (XREF_FIG, compare lanes 2 and 5, and lanes 3 and 6), suggesting that PRAK phosphorylation by p38 is also required for the optimal acetylation of PRAK by Tip60.
These results indicate that the contribution of PRAK phosphorylation and that of Tip60 phosphorylation by p38 are additive to the acetyltransferase activity of Tip60 towards PRAK.
These results indicate that the contribution of PRAK phosphorylation and that of Tip60 phosphorylation by p38 are additive to the acetyltransferase activity of Tip60 towards PRAK.

Upon activation by ras, p38 induces the acetyltransferase activity of Tip60 through phosphorylation of Thr158; activated Tip60 in turn directly interacts with and induces the protein kinase activity of PRAK through acetylation of K364 in a manner that depends on phosphorylation of both Tip60 and PRAK by p38.

Cytokine activation of ERα and endocrine resistance is dependent on phosphorylation of ERα at S305 in the hinge domain. Phosphorylation of S305 by IKKβ establishes an ERα cistrome that substantially overlaps with the estradiol (E2)-dependent ERα cistrome.

We discovered that pro inflammatory cytokine treatments activate the unliganded and TOT bound ERalpha through an IKKbeta dependent phosphorylation of ERalpha at S305, and this is sufficient to drive ERalpha dependent proliferation.

We further demonstrate that cytokine-dependent activation of ERα is driven largely by ERα-S305 phosphorylation by IKKβ, an upstream activator of NF-κB transcription.

Given that RPAP2 does not directly bind the S5P carboxyl-terminal domain , we thought other factors might be required for RPAP2 binding to RNA polymerase II.
This direct interaction also suggested RPRDs might be required for RPAP2 binding to RNA polymerase II in vivo.

Here, we show that RNA polymerase II-associated protein 2 (RPAP2) specifically recognizes the phospho-Ser7 mark on the Pol II carboxy-terminal domain and also interacts with Integrator subunits. siRNA-mediated knockdown of RPAP2 and mutation of Ser7 to alanine cause similar defects in snRNA gene expression.
We show that RPAP2 specifically associates with Ser7-phosphorylated polymerase II through a direct interaction with the carboxy-terminal domain.

The presence of the IIa and IIo forms, corresponding to hypo- and hyperphosphorylated carboxy-terminal domain, respectively, suggests that RPAP2 associates with transcriptionally active polymerase II.

After equalization of the amount of copurified polymerase II in the input, RPAP2 was found to weakly interact with unphosphorylated polymerase II, whereas Ser2P and Ser5P are readily detected in the IP, suggesting that RPAP2 interacts with transcriptionally engaged polymerase II.

These results support the notion that RPAP2 preferentially associates with Ser7-phosphorylated polymerase II and further suggests that Ser7P may be a critical determinant for its association with the polymerase machinery.
Our results indicate that RPAP2 specifically and directly interacts with the Pol II carboxy-terminal domain phosphorylated at Ser7.
